docs.title: Genji Shimada
docs.text: This documentation explains how the Genji Shimada bot, API, SDK, website, and infrastructure work together.

docs.title: What this is for
docs.text:
Genji Parkour is a custom Overwatch game mode built in Workshop. The framework for the mode lives in tylovejoy/genji-framework, and the Workshop code to play it is 54CRY.

The Genji Shimada system supports the community workflow around that mode:

  • Players submit maps for playtesting and difficulty review.
  • Approved maps are published so players can submit completion times.
  • Records, XP, and rank cards are tracked and displayed for users.
  • Newsfeed, statistics, and moderation tooling keep the community and map pipeline moving.

The system also covers:

  • Map search, guides, and edit requests.
  • Community leaderboards and statistics dashboards.
  • Lootbox rewards and XP tuning workflows.
  • OCR-assisted completion submissions.
  • Translations for UI and newsfeed content.

docs.title: What is in this repo
docs.text:
• Discord Bot — Discord automation and event handling.
  • REST API — Litestar API for maps, completions, users, and moderation workflows.
  • SDK — Shared models and client types used by services and tooling.
  • Docs for the website — The website code lives in bkan0n/genji.pk.

docs.title: Repository layout
docs.text:
The project is a monorepo with three main components:

genjishimada/
├── apps/
│   ├── api/          # Litestar REST API
│   └── bot/          # Discord.py bot
└── libs/
    └── sdk/          # Shared msgspec models

docs.title: Key technologies
docs.text:
• Python 3.13+ with uv for package management
  • Litestar for the REST API
  • Discord.py for the Discord bot
  • PostgreSQL 17 for data persistence
  • RabbitMQ for async message passing
  • msgspec for fast serialization and validation

docs.title: Community
docs.text:
• Discord Server: dsc.gg/genjiparkour
  • GitHub: bkan0n/genjishimada
  • Production API: api.genji.pk

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text: See the Contributing Guide if you want to help or test changes locally.

docs.title: API Documentation
docs.text: The Genji Shimada API is a Litestar-based REST API for maps, completions, user profiles, authentication, and related services.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The API is built with:

  • Litestar - Modern, fast Python web framework
  • AsyncPG - High-performance PostgreSQL driver
  • msgspec - Fast JSON serialization
  • RabbitMQ - Asynchronous message passing to the bot

docs.title: Base URLs
docs.text:
The API is served under the /api/v3 prefix.

  • Production: https://api.genji.pk/api/v3
  • Development: https://dev-api.genji.pk/api/v3
  • Local: http://localhost:8000/api/v3

docs.title: Quick Links
docs.text:
• OpenAPI Reference

    Browse the complete API specification

    OpenAPI Spec

  • Authentication

    Learn how API keys and scopes work

    Auth Guide

  • External API Docs

    Interactive Swagger UI hosted on the API server

    api.genji.pk/docs

docs.title: RESTful Endpoints
docs.text:
Example endpoints (all under /api/v3):

  • GET /maps - List and search maps
  • POST /completions - Submit a completion
  • GET /users/{user_id} - Get user profile
  • PUT /users/{user_id}/settings - Update user settings

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text: All endpoints require an API key unless explicitly excluded. See the Authentication Guide.

docs.title: Message Queue Integration
docs.text:
The API publishes events to RabbitMQ for asynchronous processing by the bot:

API → RabbitMQ → Bot

Examples: - Completion submissions trigger Discord notifications - Map updates notify subscribers - User achievements are announced in channels

docs.title: Database Architecture
docs.text:
The API uses PostgreSQL 17 with multiple schemas:

  • core.* - Users, maps, permissions
  • maps.* - Map metadata and ratings
  • completions.* - User completion records
  • users.* - Profiles and XP

Migrations are located in apps/api/migrations/.

docs.title: Running Locally
docs.text:
just run-api

The API starts at http://localhost:8000 with hot reload enabled.

docs.title: Interactive Docs
docs.text: Visit http://localhost:8000/docs for the Swagger UI.

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
Run the test suite:

just test-api

Tests use pytest with parallel execution (8 workers).

docs.title: Dependency Injection Pattern
docs.text:
Business logic is separated from HTTP routing:

  • apps/api/di/*.py - DI modules with business logic
  • apps/api/routes/*.py - Thin HTTP handlers

Example flow:

  1. Route handler receives request
  2. Validates parameters
  3. Calls DI function with database connection
  4. DI function performs business logic
  5. Returns serialized response

docs.title: Idempotency
docs.text: Most message queue operations are idempotent, tracked via message_id headers and database claims.

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
Custom exceptions in utilities/errors.py provide structured error responses:

from utilities.errors import CustomHTTPException

raise CustomHTTPException(
    status_code=404,
    detail="Map not found",
)

docs.title: Architecture
docs.text: This page explains how the API is organized and why certain patterns were chosen.

docs.title: Entry point (apps/api/app.py)
docs.text:
The API is assembled in a single entry point:

  • RabbitMQ connection pools are created during lifespan startup and stored in app state.
  • PostgreSQL is configured with litestar_asyncpg.AsyncpgPlugin for pooled connections.
  • OpenAPI metadata is configured and served at /docs.
  • Routing mounts a router at /api/v3 using route_handlers discovered from apps/api/routes.
  • Health check is available at /healthcheck.

docs.title: Dynamic route loading (apps/api/routes/__init__.py)
docs.text:
Routes are discovered dynamically:

  • Modules under apps/api/routes/ are imported automatically.
  • Any litestar.Router instance or litestar.Controller subclass is registered.

This keeps the entry point small and makes it easy to add new route modules.

docs.title: Controllers and dependency injection
docs.text:
Controllers focus on HTTP concerns. Domain logic lives in DI services under apps/api/di/.

Typical flow:

  1. Controller method parses input and validates types.
  2. It calls a DI service (e.g., MapService, CompletionService).
  3. Services perform DB work and publish events.
  4. The controller returns SDK response models.

docs.title: Message publishing
docs.text:
Services inherit from BaseService, which provides:

  • Access to the asyncpg connection
  • A publish_message helper that inserts a job row and publishes to RabbitMQ
  • Optional idempotency tracking for queue messages

Queues follow the pattern: api.<domain>.<action>.

docs.title: Authentication and guards
docs.text:
• CustomAuthenticationMiddleware requires X-API-KEY on requests.
  • scope_guard enforces route-level scopes via opt={"required_scopes": {...}}.
  • Routes can opt out with opt={"exclude_from_auth": True}.

docs.title: SDK integration
docs.text: The API uses models from libs/sdk (genjishimada_sdk) for request and response types, keeping shared schemas consistent across API, bot, and clients.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Local Development - Run the API locally
  • Authentication - API keys and scopes

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text: The Genji Shimada API uses API keys for all authenticated requests. This is the only supported method for service-to-service communication.

docs.title: API Keys
docs.text:
Use case: Bot, internal services, or trusted backend clients.

API keys are stored in the public.api_tokens table and attached to an auth user record.

docs.title: Using an API Key
docs.text:
Include the key in the X-API-KEY header:

curl -H "X-API-KEY: your_api_key" \
  https://api.genji.pk/api/v3/maps

Example (Python):

import httpx

headers = {"X-API-KEY": "your_api_key"}
response = httpx.get("https://api.genji.pk/api/v3/maps", headers=headers)

docs.title: Scopes
docs.text:
API keys may be scoped. The middleware attaches scopes and is_superuser to the request auth token.

Common scope examples:

  • read:maps
  • write:maps
  • read:users
  • write:completions
  • admin:*

Routes can require scopes via required_scopes:

@get(
    "/admin/users",
    opt={"required_scopes": {"admin:users"}},
)
async def list_all_users() -> list[User]:
    ...

docs.title: Middleware
docs.text: Authentication is enforced by CustomAuthenticationMiddleware in apps/api/middleware/auth.py.

docs.title: Excluding Routes from Auth
docs.text:
Routes can opt out of authentication with exclude_from_auth:

@get("/healthcheck", opt={"exclude_from_auth": True})
async def health_check() -> dict:
    return {"status": "ok"}

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Use least-privilege keys for each service.
  • Rotate keys periodically.
  • Store keys in environment variables, never in code.

docs.title: Missing API Key
docs.text:
Error: 401 Unauthorized - Missing API key

Solution: Ensure X-API-KEY is present on the request.

docs.title: Invalid API Key
docs.text:
Error: 401 Unauthorized - Invalid API key

Solution: Verify the key is correct and active.

docs.title: Insufficient Permissions
docs.text:
Error: 403 Forbidden - Missing required scopes: ...

Solution: Update the key's scopes or use a superuser token.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• OpenAPI Reference - Review endpoint auth requirements
  • External API Docs - Interactive Swagger UI

docs.title: Deployment
docs.text: This project deploys the API with Docker Compose. The exact deployment workflow (CI/CD, SSH, etc.) depends on your environment.

docs.title: Production compose
docs.text:
The production compose file defines these services:

  • genjishimada-api
  • genjishimada-bot
  • genjishimada-db
  • genjishimada-rabbitmq

Start them with:

docker compose -f docker-compose.prod.yml up -d

docs.title: Environment variables
docs.text:
Create a production .env with the values required by the API and bot:

APP_ENVIRONMENT=production
POSTGRES_USER=genjishimada
POSTGRES_PASSWORD=your_password
POSTGRES_DB=genjishimada
RABBITMQ_USER=admin
RABBITMQ_PASS=your_password
RABBITMQ_HOST=genjishimada-rabbitmq
API_KEY=your_api_key_for_bot

Add any optional values (Sentry, R2, Resend) as needed.

docs.title: Health checks
docs.text: The API service includes a health check at /healthcheck. Within Docker, this runs on http://localhost:8000/healthcheck inside the container. Expose it through your reverse proxy if you need external access.

docs.title: Logs
docs.text: docker compose -f docker-compose.prod.yml logs -f genjishimada-api

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: RabbitMQ and Postgres are attached to the external genji-network. Ensure that network exists in your environment.

docs.title: Local Development
docs.text: How to run the API locally for development and testing.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Docker and Docker Compose
  • Python 3.13+
  • uv and just

docs.title: Environment variables
docs.text:
Create a .env file at the repo root with at least:

APP_ENVIRONMENT=development
POSTGRES_USER=genjishimada
POSTGRES_PASSWORD=your_password
POSTGRES_DB=genjishimada
RABBITMQ_USER=admin
RABBITMQ_PASS=your_password
RABBITMQ_HOST=localhost
API_KEY=your_api_key_for_bot

If you are running the API in Docker, set RABBITMQ_HOST=genjishimada-rabbitmq-dev.

If you are running the API on the host, set PSQL_DSN so it points at the mapped Postgres port:

PSQL_DSN=postgresql://genjishimada:your_password@localhost:65432/genjishimada

Add any optional values you need (Sentry, R2, Resend).

docs.title: Start infrastructure
docs.text:
Start the database and RabbitMQ only:

docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml up -d \
  genjishimada-db-dev \
  genjishimada-rabbitmq-dev

docs.title: Run the API on the host
docs.text:
just run-api

The API starts at http://localhost:8000.

docs.title: Health check
docs.text: curl http://localhost:8000/healthcheck

docs.title: Swagger UI
docs.text: Open http://localhost:8000/docs.

docs.title: Run the API in Docker (optional)
docs.text:
If you want Docker to run everything, use the compose service:

docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml up -d genjishimada-api-dev

This expects the same .env variables.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• Database connection errors: confirm genjishimada-db-dev is healthy.
  • RabbitMQ connection errors: confirm genjishimada-rabbitmq-dev is healthy.

Download Spec

docs.title: Generating the Spec Locally
docs.text:
To regenerate the OpenAPI spec from the Litestar app:

uv run --project apps/api python scripts/generate_openapi.py

To build the documentation site afterward:

uv run --project docs mkdocs build

docs.title: Import into Postman
docs.text:
1. Download openapi.json
  2. Open Postman
  3. Click Import → Upload Files
  4. Select the downloaded openapi.json

docs.title: Generate Client SDKs
docs.text:
Use tools like openapi-generator to generate client libraries:

openapi-generator-cli generate \
  -i docs/openapi.json \
  -g python \
  -o ./generated-client

docs.title: Validate Requests
docs.text: Use the spec to validate API requests in your tests or CI/CD pipeline.

docs.title: Specification Details
docs.text:
The OpenAPI spec includes:

  • All endpoints with request/response schemas
  • Authentication requirements (API key and scopes)
  • Error responses with status codes and messages
  • Data models for all request and response bodies

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text: The spec documents API key authentication via the X-API-KEY header.

docs.title: Endpoints
docs.text:
Major endpoint groups:

  • /maps - Map CRUD and search
  • /completions - Completion submissions and tracking
  • /users - User profiles and settings
  • /auth - Email-based authentication endpoints
  • /notifications - Notification delivery
  • /lootbox - Lootbox system

docs.title: Models
docs.text: All request/response bodies use msgspec Struct definitions from libs/sdk.

docs.title: Bot Documentation
docs.text: The Genji Shimada Discord bot is built with discord.py and provides interactive features for the Genji Parkour community.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The bot handles:

  • User commands - Interactive Discord slash commands
  • Event processing - Async message queue consumers
  • Notifications - Discord notifications for completions, maps, and achievements
  • Integration - Seamless integration with the REST API

docs.title: Quick Links
docs.text:
• Architecture

    Learn how the bot is structured

    Core Bot

  • Messaging

    Understand RabbitMQ queue consumers

    Messaging

  • Configuration

    Configure the bot for your environment

    Configuration

docs.title: Slash Commands
docs.text:
The bot uses Discord's slash commands for user interaction:

@app_commands.command(name="map")
async def map_command(interaction: discord.Interaction, map_code: str):
    """Search for a map by code."""
    ...

docs.title: Queue Consumers
docs.text:
The bot consumes events from RabbitMQ:

@queue_consumer("api.completion.submission", struct_type=CompletionCreatedEvent)
async def handle_completion(event: CompletionCreatedEvent, message: AbstractIncomingMessage) -> None:
    # Send Discord notification
    ...

docs.title: API Integration
docs.text:
The bot calls the API through APIService attached to bot.api:

map_data = await bot.api.get_map(map_code)

docs.title: Bot Structure
docs.text:
apps/bot/
├── core/
│   └── genji.py           # Main bot class
├── extensions/            # Feature modules
│   ├── rabbit.py          # RabbitMQ service
│   ├── api_service.py     # API client
│   ├── completions.py     # Completion handlers
│   └── ...
├── configs/               # Configuration files
│   ├── dev.toml
│   └── prod.toml
└── main.py                # Entry point

docs.title: Development
docs.text:
docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml up -d genjishimada-bot-dev

If you run the bot on the host with just run-bot, ensure the API hostname (genjishimada-api-dev) resolves locally.

docs.title: Production
docs.text: docker compose -f docker-compose.prod.yml up -d genjishimada-bot

docs.title: Core Bot Lifecycle
docs.text: This page details how the main Discord process boots, wires shared services, and loads extensions.

docs.title: Entry point
docs.text:
The bot starts in apps/bot/main.py inside the main() coroutine. The sequence is:

  1. Configure Sentry (when SENTRY_DSN is present) and set up filtered Discord logging via setup_logging().
  2. Create an aiohttp.ClientSession and instantiate core.Genji, passing the configured prefix ("?" in production, "!" otherwise).
  3. Start the asynchronous context manager for the bot and call bot.start(DISCORD_TOKEN) to connect to the Discord gateway.

core/genji.py defines the Genji subclass of commands.Bot. During __init__ the class:

  • Applies the gateway intents defined at module level.
  • Stores the shared HTTP session and constructs a VideoThumbnailService helper.
  • Loads configs/prod.toml when APP_ENVIRONMENT is "production", or configs/dev.toml for all other environments, using the utilities.config.decode helper.

docs.title: Extension loading
docs.text:
Genji.setup_hook runs once the Discord connection is preparing. It loads every module under extensions/ (discovered via pkgutil in extensions.__init__.EXTENSIONS) plus the debugging cog jishaku. After extensions are loaded, the method schedules self.rabbit.start() on the bot loop so that queue consumers begin once all handlers are registered.

Each extension exposes an async setup(bot) function that attaches services or cogs to the bot. Notable patterns include:

  • extensions.api_service.setup instantiates APIService and assigns it to bot.api for use across other modules.
  • extensions.newsfeed.setup, extensions.completions.setup, extensions.playtest.setup, and extensions.xp.setup create service classes that are stored on the bot for later access.
  • extensions.notifications.setup attaches NotificationService to bot.notifications.
  • extensions.rabbit.setup prepares the RabbitService, which setup_hook starts after all handlers are registered.

docs.title: Service lifecycle
docs.text:
Service classes that inherit from utilities.base.BaseService (for example CompletionsService, PlaytestService, and XPService) lazily resolve the configured guild and their target channels. The base class spawns a task that waits for the bot to become ready, fetches bot.config.guild, and calls each service's _resolve_channels() hook before handling work.

When adding a new feature module:

  1. Create an extension module under extensions/ with an async def setup(bot) entry point.
  2. Attach any long-lived service to the bot (optionally inheriting from BaseService).
  3. Register queue handlers with queue_consumer if the feature processes RabbitMQ events (see Messaging & Queues).
  4. Ensure the module is importable so that extensions.__init__ discovers it automatically during startup.

docs.title: File Locations
docs.text:
All bot code is located in apps/bot/:

apps/bot/
├── main.py               # Entry point
├── core/
│   └── genji.py          # Main bot class
├── extensions/           # Feature modules
│   ├── __init__.py       # Extension discovery
│   ├── api_service.py    # API client
│   ├── rabbit.py         # RabbitMQ service
│   ├── newsfeed.py       # Newsfeed service
│   ├── completions.py    # Completions service
│   ├── playtest.py       # Playtest service
│   ├── notifications.py  # Notification service
│   └── xp.py             # XP service
├── utilities/            # Shared utilities
│   ├── base.py           # BaseService
│   ├── config.py         # Config schema
│   └── formatter.py      # Embed formatters
└── configs/              # TOML configuration
    ├── dev.toml
    └── prod.toml

docs.title: Messaging & Queues
docs.text: The bot consumes RabbitMQ queues to react to events emitted by the Genji Parkour API. Queue handlers live alongside their feature modules and are registered through a shared decorator.

docs.title: RabbitMQ integration
docs.text:
• extensions/_queue_registry.py provides queue_consumer, which wraps handlers with decoding, idempotency, and pytest short-circuit logic.
  • extensions/rabbit.RabbitService opens pooled connections to RabbitMQ, declares queues (and matching dead-letter queues), wraps handlers for error handling, and tracks startup drain state. The client is created during the extensions.rabbit setup hook and started from Genji.setup_hook.
  • Services can call await bot.rabbit.wait_until_drained() when they need to delay work until any startup backlog has been processed (for example, before sending verification embeds or playtest updates).

docs.title: Queue handler lifecycle
docs.text:
1. Decorate an async function or method with @queue_consumer("queue-name", struct_type=...) inside the relevant extension module.
  2. Parse the message body with msgspec models before touching Discord state.
  3. Perform the required Discord or API calls. The wrapper created by RabbitService manages acknowledgements and ensures failures are logged before the message is dead-lettered.

docs.title: Queue naming convention
docs.text:
Queues follow the pattern: api.<domain>.<action>

Examples: - api.newsfeed.create - api.completion.submission - api.playtest.create

docs.title: Queue catalog
docs.text:
Queue Handler Notes api.newsfeed.create NewsfeedService._process_newsfeed_create Fetches the new event and posts it to the configured newsfeed channel. api.notification.delivery NotificationService._process_notification_delivery Sends DMs or channel notifications based on user settings. api.completion.autoverification.failed CompletionsService._process_autoverification_failed Handles failed autoverification results. api.completion.upvote CompletionsService._process_update_upvote_message Forwards completion submissions into the upvote channel. api.completion.submission CompletionsService._process_create_submission_message Builds the verification queue embed for a new completion submission. api.completion.verification CompletionsService._process_verification_status_change Updates verification state and notifies users. api.playtest.create PlaytestService._process_create_playtest_message Creates playtest threads and posts the intake embed. api.playtest.vote.cast PlaytestService._process_vote_cast_message Records a new playtest vote and grants XP. api.playtest.vote.remove PlaytestService._process_vote_remove_message Handles vote removal events. api.playtest.approve PlaytestService._process_playtest_approve_message Posts approval summaries and cleans up playtest state. api.playtest.force_accept PlaytestService._process_playtest_force_accept_message Mirrors force-accept commands issued upstream. api.playtest.force_deny PlaytestService._process_playtest_force_deny_message Mirrors force-deny commands issued upstream. api.playtest.reset PlaytestService._process_playtest_reset_message Resets playtest runs and refreshes Discord embeds. api.xp.grant XPService._process_grant_message Applies XP rewards announced by the API. api.map_edit.created MapEditorService._process_edit_created Creates a verification view for new map edit requests. api.map_edit.resolved MapEditorService._process_edit_resolved Cleans up the verification queue message once resolved.

Keep this table current as new queues are introduced so on-call maintainers can trace message flow quickly.

docs.title: Idempotency
docs.text:
Most queues enforce idempotency using message_id headers:

API side (publishing): 

await self.publish_message(
    queue_name="api.completion.submission",
    message=event,
    message_id=f"completion-{completion_id}",  # Unique ID
)

Bot side (consuming): 

@queue_consumer("api.completion.submission", struct_type=CompletionCreatedEvent, idempotent=True)
async def handle_completion(self, event: CompletionCreatedEvent, message: AbstractIncomingMessage) -> None:
    # Handler only runs once per message_id
    ...

Claims are tracked in the database to prevent duplicate processing.

docs.title: Pytest short-circuit
docs.text: Queue consumers skip processing when a message header includes x-pytest-enabled: 1. This is used in integration tests to avoid side effects.

docs.title: Dead Letter Queue (DLQ)
docs.text:
Failed messages are moved to a dead letter queue (e.g., api.completion.submission.dlq) after exhausting retries.

DLQ Processor (runs every 60 seconds): 1. Checks DLQ for messages 2. Posts alert to Discord with message details 3. Marks message with dlq_notified header 4. Prevents duplicate alerts

docs.title: Services & Extensions
docs.text: Services encapsulate long-lived Discord behaviour, while extensions expose the asynchronous setup hook that registers those services and any associated cogs.

docs.title: Service catalog
docs.text:
Service Module / Class Responsibilities API client extensions/api_service.py → APIService Maintains an authenticated aiohttp session to the API and exposes helpers for maps, completions, playtests, and notifications. Stored on bot.api. RabbitMQ extensions/rabbit.py → RabbitService Connects to RabbitMQ using pooled channels, declares queues (and DLQs), wraps handlers registered through queue_consumer, and exposes helpers such as publish and wait_until_drained. Stored on bot.rabbit. Notifications extensions/notifications.py → NotificationService Determines whether a user has opted into specific notification bitmasks and sends DMs or channel pings accordingly. Stored on bot.notifications. Newsfeed extensions/newsfeed.py → NewsfeedService Registers builders for each newsfeed payload type, publishes events into the configured channel, and consumes api.newsfeed.create messages. Stored on bot.newsfeed. Completions extensions/completions.py → CompletionsService Resolves verification channels, renders verification views, emits follow-up newsfeed events, and handles completion-related queues. Stored on bot.completions. Playtest extensions/playtest.py → PlaytestService Manages playtest threads, queue-driven state changes, and XP grants tied to votes. Stored on bot.playtest. XP extensions/xp.py → XPService Resolves XP channels, applies XP grants from the api.xp.grant queue, and exposes helpers for other services to award XP. Stored on bot.xp. Map edits extensions/moderator.py → MapEditorService Manages map edit verification views and listens to map edit queues. Stored on bot.map_editor. Thumbnails extensions/video_thumbnail.py → VideoThumbnailService Generates video thumbnails for embeds and newsfeed entries. Stored on bot.thumbnail_service.

Extend this table as new extensions ship so there is a single map of the long-lived services attached to the bot instance.

docs.title: Extension anatomy
docs.text:
1. Setup hook: Each extension defines async def setup(bot) and attaches services, cogs, or background tasks.
  2. Shared state: Services either use property setters on Genji (for example bot.api) or inherit from utilities.base.BaseService to gain guild/channel resolution helpers.
  3. Queue registration: Background work is tied to RabbitMQ queues by decorating handler coroutines with @queue_consumer("queue-name").
  4. Cross-extension collaboration: Services call into one another via the properties on bot. For example, the completions flow calls bot.api to fetch payloads, uses bot.notifications to determine DM preferences, and leverages bot.xp to grant XP during verification updates.

docs.title: BaseService
docs.text:
The utilities.base.BaseService class provides common functionality for services:

from utilities.base import BaseService

class MyService(BaseService):
    async def _resolve_channels(self) -> None:
        """Called after bot is ready and guild is resolved."""
        self.my_channel = await self.guild.fetch_channel(channel_id)

    async def do_work(self) -> None:
        """Service methods can access self.guild and resolved channels."""
        await self.my_channel.send("Hello!")

Features: - Automatic guild resolution - Channel resolution hook - Access to bot instance

docs.title: Creating a New Extension
docs.text:
To add a new feature to the bot:

  1. Create the extension file: 

    apps/bot/extensions/my_feature.py

  2. Define the setup function: 

    async def setup(bot):
    service = MyService(bot)
    bot.my_service = service

  3. Optionally create a service: 

    from utilities.base import BaseService

class MyService(BaseService):
    async def _resolve_channels(self) -> None:
        # Resolve channels here
        pass

  4. Register queue handlers (if needed): 

    from extensions._queue_registry import queue_consumer

@queue_consumer("api.my_feature.event", struct_type=MyEvent)
async def handle_event(self, event: MyEvent, message: AbstractIncomingMessage):
    # Process the event
    pass

  5. Import in extensions/__init__.py: 

    EXTENSIONS = [
    # ...
    "extensions.my_feature",
]

Document queues, commands, and presentation helpers in the relevant sections when adding new functionality so future contributors can follow the established patterns.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Core Bot Lifecycle - Understand bot startup
  • Messaging & Queues - Learn about queue handlers
  • Newsfeed & Embeds - UI guidelines
  • Configuration - Configure the bot

docs.title: Configuration & Deployment
docs.text: Use this page to wire environment variables, TOML configuration, and deployment workflows for the Genji Shimada bot.

docs.title: Environment configuration
docs.text: Runtime settings come from a combination of environment variables and a TOML file loaded at startup.

docs.title: Core variables
docs.text:
Required environment variables in .env:

  • DISCORD_TOKEN – Required by bot.start(). Obtain from Discord Developer Portal.
  • APP_ENVIRONMENT – Controls the command prefix and which TOML file is loaded:
  • "production" → loads configs/prod.toml, uses "?" prefix
  • Any other value → loads configs/dev.toml, uses "!" prefix
  • API_KEY – Forwarded to the APIService for authenticated requests to the API.
  • API hostnames are derived from APP_ENVIRONMENT (genjishimada-api-dev for development, genjishimada-api for production).

docs.title: RabbitMQ variables
docs.text:
Required for message queue integration:

  • RABBITMQ_USER – RabbitMQ username
  • RABBITMQ_PASS – RabbitMQ password
  • RABBITMQ_HOST – RabbitMQ host (e.g., localhost or genjishimada-rabbitmq in Docker)

docs.title: Optional observability variables
docs.text:
For error tracking and monitoring:

  • SENTRY_DSN – Sentry DSN for error tracking
  • SENTRY_AUTH_TOKEN – Sentry auth token (optional)
  • SENTRY_FEEDBACK_URL – Custom feedback URL (optional)

docs.title: TOML configuration
docs.text: The TOML schema is defined in utilities/config.py and covers guild, role, and channel identifiers.

docs.title: Development configuration
docs.text:
Edit apps/bot/configs/dev.toml for development IDs:

[guild]
id = 1234567890  # Your development Discord server ID

[channels]
newsfeed = 1234567890
completions_verification = 1234567890
completions_upvote = 1234567890
playtest = 1234567890
xp = 1234567890
logs = 1234567890

[roles]
admin = 1234567890
moderator = 1234567890
verified = 1234567890

docs.title: Production configuration
docs.text:
Edit apps/bot/configs/prod.toml for production IDs:

[guild]
id = 9876543210  # Production Discord server ID

[channels]
newsfeed = 9876543210
completions_verification = 9876543210
completions_upvote = 9876543210
playtest = 9876543210
xp = 9876543210
logs = 9876543210

[roles]
admin = 9876543210
moderator = 9876543210
verified = 9876543210

The Genji constructor reads the appropriate file on startup based on APP_ENVIRONMENT.

docs.title: Local development workflow
docs.text:
1. Install dependencies: 

    just setup

  2. Configure environment: create a .env file and add your variables.

  3. Edit development config: 

    # Edit apps/bot/configs/dev.toml with your Discord IDs

  4. Start infrastructure: 

    docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml up -d \
  genjishimada-db-dev \
  genjishimada-rabbitmq-dev

  5. Run the bot: 

    docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml up -d genjishimada-bot-dev

If you run the bot on the host with just run-bot, ensure the API hostname (genjishimada-api-dev) resolves locally.

  1. Lint before committing: 
    just lint-bot

docs.title: Development
docs.text:
If you run the bot inside Docker:

docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml up -d genjishimada-bot-dev

docs.title: Production
docs.text:
Use the production compose file:

docker compose -f docker-compose.prod.yml up -d genjishimada-bot

docs.title: Deployment checklist
docs.text:
Before deploying to production:

  • Update configs/prod.toml with production Discord IDs
  • Set all required environment variables in production .env
  • Ensure RabbitMQ and the Genji API are reachable
  • Build and deploy the container image (or restart the process)
  • Monitor Discord logs and Sentry events after rollout
  • Verify bot appears online in Discord
  • Test key commands and queue consumers

docs.title: Logging
docs.text:
setup_logging() in main.py configures log levels and filters:

  • Filters noisy Discord messages
  • Enables DEBUG logs for internal packages when APP_ENVIRONMENT is "development"
  • Logs to console by default

View logs:

# Local development
just run-bot

# Docker
docker compose -f docker-compose.prod.yml logs -f genjishimada-bot

docs.title: Sentry
docs.text:
main() initializes Sentry with trace and profile sampling when SENTRY_DSN is set:

import sentry_sdk
from sentry_sdk.integrations.asyncio import AsyncioIntegration

sentry_sdk.init(
    dsn=SENTRY_DSN,
    environment=APP_ENVIRONMENT,
    integrations=[AsyncioIntegration()],
)

Benefits: - Automatic exception capture - Performance traces - User context (Discord user info)

View errors at sentry.io.

docs.title: Bot Won't Start
docs.text:
Check Discord token: 

# Verify DISCORD_TOKEN is set
echo $DISCORD_TOKEN

Check permissions: - Ensure bot has required intents enabled in Discord Developer Portal - Verify bot is invited to the server with correct permissions

Check logs: 

docker compose -f docker-compose.prod.yml logs genjishimada-bot

docs.title: Queue Messages Not Processing
docs.text:
Verify RabbitMQ connection: 

# Check RabbitMQ is running
docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml ps genjishimada-rabbitmq-dev

# Check bot logs for connection errors
docker compose -f docker-compose.prod.yml logs genjishimada-bot | grep -i rabbitmq

Check queue consumers: - Inspect bot logs for queue bindings and errors

docs.title: API Requests Failing
docs.text:
Verify API key: 

# Check API_KEY is set
echo $API_KEY

Check API availability: 

curl -H "X-API-KEY: $API_KEY" http://localhost:8000/healthcheck

Check bot logs: 

docker compose -f docker-compose.prod.yml logs genjishimada-bot | grep -i api

docs.text:

  • Services & Extensions - Learn about services
  • Operations Guide - Infrastructure overview
  • Docker Compose - Deployment guide

docs.title: Developer Utilities
docs.text: This page lists helper classes used throughout the bot to keep common patterns consistent.

docs.title: Formatting Helpers
docs.text:
Location: apps/bot/utilities/formatter.py

A formattable model implements to_format_dict() and returns a mapping of display labels to string values. The formatter uses this mapping to build a readable block for embeds and messages.

The interface lives in apps/bot/utilities/formatter.py:

class FormattableProtocol(Protocol):
    def to_format_dict(self) -> dict[str, str | None]:
        ...

Two formatters are available:

  • Formatter - draws a tree-like list with ┣/┗ prefix characters.
  • FilteredFormatter - renders blockquote-style lines and lets you exclude fields.

Both drop keys whose values are None, False, or empty strings.

docs.title: Example: format a completion payload
docs.text:
CompletionSubmissionModel implements to_format_dict() in apps/bot/utilities/completions.py.

from utilities.completions import CompletionSubmissionModel
from utilities.formatter import Formatter

model = CompletionSubmissionModel(**payload)
formatted = Formatter(model).format()

# Use in an embed description or message body
embed.description = formatted

docs.title: Example: filter fields
docs.text:
Use FilteredFormatter when you want a smaller summary:

from utilities.maps import MapModel
from utilities.formatter import FilteredFormatter

model = MapModel(**payload)
formatted = FilteredFormatter(
    model,
    filter_fields={"Mechanics", "Restrictions"},
).format()

docs.title: Implementing a new formattable
docs.text:
Wrap SDK models or view models in a small class that implements to_format_dict().

class MyFormattable:
    def __init__(self, name: str, score: int) -> None:
        self.name = name
        self.score = score

    def to_format_dict(self) -> dict[str, str | None]:
        return {
            "Name": self.name,
            "Score": str(self.score),
        }

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
• Keep keys short and consistent (Code, Map, Time).
  • Return "" for optional fields you want hidden.
  • Use inline Markdown sparingly (e.g., "[Link](...)").

docs.title: BaseView Helpers
docs.text:
Location: apps/bot/utilities/base.py

BaseView is the common base for Components V2 views. It handles timeouts and delegates errors to the shared app command error handler. If you build a view on top of BaseView, you are in the same error handling flow as the rest of the bot.

Key points:

  • rebuild_components() is the hook you override to re-render the view.
  • _end_time_string is updated on timeout and can be included in the UI.
  • on_error() delegates to the app command error handler.

docs.title: Example: BaseView rebuild pattern
docs.text:
from discord import ui
from utilities.base import BaseView

class MyView(BaseView):
    def rebuild_components(self) -> None:
        self.clear_items()
        container = ui.Container(
            ui.TextDisplay("# My View Title"),
            ui.Separator(),
            ui.TextDisplay("Body text goes here."),
            ui.Separator(),
            ui.TextDisplay(f"# {self._end_time_string}"),
        )
        self.add_item(container)

Important

When you call rebuild_components() from inside a component callback, the component's self.view becomes None. If you need to reference the view after rebuilding, store it in a local variable before rebuilding.

docs.title: Pagination Helpers
docs.text:
Location: apps/bot/utilities/paginator.py

PaginatorView is a base view for paging through lists with buttons (next, previous, and page number). It provides a consistent UI for multi-page results and handles view state for you.

Used by multiple extensions, for example: - apps/bot/extensions/completions.py (leaderboards, user pages) - apps/bot/extensions/map_search.py (search and guides) - apps/bot/extensions/moderator.py (moderation panels)

docs.title: Example: paginator subclass
docs.text:
PaginatorView expects a title and a sequence of formattable items. You implement build_page_body() to render the current page, and you can optionally add a second row via build_additional_action_row().

from discord import ui
from utilities.formatter import Formatter
from utilities.paginator import PaginatorView

class GuidePaginator(PaginatorView[FormattableGuide]):
    def build_page_body(self) -> list[ui.Item]:
        lines = []
        for item in self.current_page:
            lines.append(ui.TextDisplay(Formatter(item).format()))
        return lines

    def build_additional_action_row(self) -> ui.ActionRow | None:
        return ui.ActionRow(ui.Button(label="Refresh", custom_id="refresh"))

view = GuidePaginator("Guides", guides, page_size=5)
view.original_interaction = itx
await itx.response.send_message(view=view)

The paginator rebuilds its components on every page change by calling rebuild_components().

Important

The same self.view behavior applies inside pagination button callbacks. Save the view to a local variable before rebuilding if you need to reference it after the rebuild.

docs.title: Error Handling Helpers
docs.text:
Location: apps/bot/utilities/errors.py

  • UserFacingError - Exceptions meant to show a clear message to the user.
  • ErrorView - Standard error UI with a feedback button.

docs.title: Interaction behavior
docs.text:
• Any view that subclasses BaseView uses the shared error handler.
  • If you raise UserFacingError inside an interaction, the error message is shown to the user.
  • Any non-UserFacingError is shown as an unknown error.
  • In both cases, users can submit feedback, which is sent to Sentry.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Services & Extensions
  • Messaging & Queues

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text: Thank you for your interest in contributing to Genji Shimada! This guide will help you get started.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Fork and clone the repository
  2. Install dependencies: just setup
  3. Create a branch for your changes
  4. Make your changes and test them
  5. Submit a pull request

docs.title: Code of Conduct
docs.text: Be respectful, constructive, and welcoming to all contributors. We're building this together.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Ensure you have the required tools installed:

  • Python 3.13+
  • uv (package manager)
  • Docker (for databases)
  • just (task runner)

See the Installation Guide for setup instructions.

docs.title: Development Workflow
docs.text:
1. Create a feature branch: 

    git checkout -b feature/your-feature-name

  2. Make changes to the codebase

  3. Run linters: 

    just lint-all

  4. Run tests: 

    just test-all

  5. Commit your changes: 

    git add .
git commit -m "Add feature: your feature description"

  6. Push to your fork: 

    git push origin feature/your-feature-name

  7. Open a pull request on GitHub

docs.title: Project Structure
docs.text:
genjishimada/
├── apps/
│   ├── api/          # Litestar REST API
│   │   ├── di/       # Business logic (DI modules)
│   │   ├── routes/   # HTTP route handlers
│   │   ├── middleware/ # Auth and request processing
│   │   └── tests/    # API tests
│   └── bot/          # Discord bot
│       ├── core/     # Bot core (Genji class)
│       ├── extensions/ # Feature modules (cogs)
│       └── docs/     # Bot-specific docs (legacy)
├── libs/
│   └── sdk/          # Shared msgspec models
│       └── src/genjishimada_sdk/
├── docs/             # Documentation (MkDocs)
├── infra/            # Infrastructure configs
└── ops/              # Operations scripts

docs.title: Python Style
docs.text:
We use Ruff for formatting and linting, and BasedPyright for type checking.

Key rules:

  • Line length: 120 characters
  • Docstring style: Google
  • Type hints required for all function signatures
  • Import sorting enabled

Run linters:

just lint-all

docs.title: Type Annotations
docs.text:
All functions must have type annotations:

# Good
async def get_map(map_id: int) -> MapResponse:
    ...


# Bad
async def get_map(map_id):
    ...

docs.title: Docstrings
docs.text:
Use Google-style docstrings:

def process_completion(completion_id: int, user_id: int) -> bool:
    """Process a user's completion submission.

    Args:
        completion_id: The unique ID of the completion.
        user_id: The ID of the user who submitted the completion.

    Returns:
        True if processing succeeded, False otherwise.

    Raises:
        ValueError: If the completion_id is invalid.
    """
    ...

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
Use custom exceptions from utilities/errors.py:

from utilities.errors import CustomHTTPException

if not map_exists:
    raise CustomHTTPException(
        status_code=404,
        detail="Map not found"
    )

docs.title: Writing Tests
docs.text:
Tests are located in apps/api/tests/.

Example:

import pytest
from httpx import AsyncClient


@pytest.mark.asyncio
async def test_get_map(client: AsyncClient):
    response = await client.get("/maps/1")
    assert response.status_code == 200
    assert response.json()["name"] == "Test Map"

docs.title: Running Tests
docs.text:
Run all tests:

just test-all

Run API tests only:

just test-api

Run specific test file:

uv run --project apps/api pytest apps/api/tests/test_maps.py

docs.title: Test Database
docs.text: Tests use an isolated PostgreSQL database, automatically created and torn down by pytest-databases.

docs.title: Mocking
docs.text:
Use pytest fixtures for mocking:

@pytest.fixture
def mock_rabbitmq():
    return AsyncMock()

docs.title: Database Migrations
docs.text: Migrations are manual. There is no migration runner in this repo.

docs.title: Creating Migrations
docs.text:
1. Create a new SQL file in apps/api/migrations/: 

    touch apps/api/migrations/0004_add_new_feature.sql

  2. Write the migration: 

    CREATE TABLE new_feature (
    id serial PRIMARY KEY,
    name text NOT NULL
);

  3. Apply the migration manually using your preferred Postgres client. Example (dev container): 

    docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml exec genjishimada-db-dev \
  psql -U genjishimada -d genjishimada -f /path/to/migrations/0004_add_new_feature.sql

docs.title: Migration Guidelines
docs.text:
• Name files sequentially: 0001, 0002, etc.
  • Include comments explaining the purpose
  • Test on a copy of production data
  • Keep migrations small and focused

docs.title: Before Submitting
docs.text:
1. Lint your code: just lint-all
  2. Run tests: just test-all
  3. Update documentation if needed
  4. Write a clear commit message

docs.title: PR Title Format
docs.text:
Use conventional commit format:

  • feat: Add new map search endpoint
  • fix: Resolve completion verification bug
  • docs: Update API authentication guide
  • refactor: Simplify DI module structure
  • test: Add tests for lootbox system

docs.title: PR Description
docs.text:
Include:

  • What: What does this PR do?
  • Why: Why is this change needed?
  • How: How does it work?
  • Testing: How was it tested?

docs.title: Review Process
docs.text:
1. A maintainer will review your PR
  2. Address any requested changes
  3. Once approved, your PR will be merged

docs.title: Good First Issues
docs.text: Look for issues labeled good first issue on GitHub.

docs.title: Feature Requests
docs.text: Have an idea? Open an issue to discuss it first.

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text: Improve or expand the documentation in the docs/ directory.

docs.title: Bug Fixes
docs.text: Found a bug? Submit a fix with tests.

docs.title: Communication
docs.text:
• GitHub Issues: For bug reports and feature requests
  • Discord: Join the Genji Parkour server for discussions

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Development Workflow - Detailed workflow guide
  • Documentation Guide - Contributing to docs
  • Getting Started - Set up your environment

docs.title: Documentation Guide
docs.text: How to contribute to and maintain the Genji Shimada documentation.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The documentation is built with MkDocs Material and hosted on GitHub Pages at docs.genji.pk.

docs.title: Documentation Structure
docs.text:
docs/
├── index.md                    # Home page
├── services/                   # Service-level docs
├── getting-started/            # Installation and quickstart
├── bot/                        # Bot documentation
├── api/                        # API documentation
├── sdk/                        # SDK documentation
├── web/                        # Website documentation
├── operations/                 # Infrastructure and deployment
├── contributing/               # Contribution guides
├── stylesheets/
│   └── extra.css               # Custom Tailwind colors
└── openapi.json                # Generated OpenAPI spec

docs.title: Preview Documentation
docs.text:
Serve the docs locally with live reload:

just docs-serve

Visit http://127.0.0.1:8000 to view the documentation.

docs.title: Build Documentation
docs.text:
Generate the OpenAPI spec and build the site:

uv run --project apps/api python scripts/generate_openapi.py
uv run --project docs mkdocs build

Output is in site/.

docs.title: Markdown Basics
docs.text:
Use GitHub-flavored Markdown with MkDocs Material extensions.

Headings:

# H1 - Page Title
## H2 - Section
### H3 - Subsection

Links:

[Link text](../other-page.md)
[External link](https://example.com)

Code blocks:

```python
def hello():
    print("Hello, world!")
```

Inline code:

Use `just run-api` to start the server.

docs.title: Admonitions
docs.text:
Highlight important information:

!!! note
    This is a note.

!!! warning
    This is a warning.

!!! tip
    This is a tip.

!!! danger
    This is a danger alert.

Result:

Note

This is a note.

docs.title: Code Annotations
docs.text:
Add explanations to code blocks:

```python
def process(data):  # (1)!
    return data * 2
```

1. Multiply the input by 2

docs.title: Development Workflow
docs.text: Detailed guide for developing features and fixing bugs in Genji Shimada.

docs.title: 1. Fork the Repository
docs.text:
Click "Fork" on GitHub to create your own copy:

https://github.com/bkan0n/genjishimada

docs.title: 2. Clone Your Fork
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/genjishimada.git
cd genjishimada

docs.title: 3. Add Upstream Remote
docs.text: git remote add upstream https://github.com/bkan0n/genjishimada.git

docs.title: 4. Install Dependencies
docs.text: just setup

docs.title: 5. Configure Environment
docs.text: Create a .env file in the repo root and set the required variables.

docs.title: 6. Start Infrastructure
docs.text:
docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml up -d \
  genjishimada-db-dev \
  genjishimada-rabbitmq-dev

docs.title: 1. Sync with Upstream
docs.text:
Before starting work, sync your fork:

git checkout main
git fetch upstream
git merge upstream/main
git push origin main

docs.title: 2. Create a Feature Branch
docs.text:
git checkout -b feature/your-feature-name

Branch naming conventions: - feature/ - New features - fix/ - Bug fixes - docs/ - Documentation changes - refactor/ - Code refactoring - test/ - Test improvements

docs.title: 3. Make Changes
docs.text: Edit code, add tests, update documentation.

docs.title: 4. Run Linters
docs.text:
just lint-all

This runs: - Ruff (formatting and linting) - BasedPyright (type checking)

Fix linting issues: 

# Format code
uv run ruff format .

# Auto-fix linting issues
uv run ruff check --fix .

docs.title: 5. Run Tests
docs.text:
just test-all

For faster iteration, run specific tests:

# API tests only
just test-api

# Specific test file
uv run --project apps/api pytest apps/api/tests/test_maps.py

# Specific test function
uv run --project apps/api pytest apps/api/tests/test_maps.py::test_get_map

docs.title: 6. Commit Changes
docs.text:
Write clear, descriptive commit messages:

git add .
git commit -m "feat: add map search endpoint

- Add /maps/search route with query parameters
- Implement full-text search using PostgreSQL
- Add tests for search functionality
"

Commit message format:

<type>: <short description>

<detailed description>

<footer (optional)>

Types: - feat - New feature - fix - Bug fix - docs - Documentation - refactor - Code refactoring - test - Test improvements - chore - Maintenance tasks

docs.title: 7. Push to Your Fork
docs.text: git push origin feature/your-feature-name

docs.title: 8. Open a Pull Request
docs.text:
1. Go to your fork on GitHub
  2. Click "Compare & pull request"
  3. Fill out the PR template
  4. Submit the PR

docs.title: Project Structure
docs.text:
apps/api/
├── di/                # Business logic (DI modules)
│   ├── base.py        # BaseService with RabbitMQ publishing
│   ├── auth.py        # Authentication logic
│   ├── maps.py        # Map CRUD operations
│   └── completions.py # Completion tracking
├── routes/            # HTTP route handlers
│   ├── maps/          # Map-related routes
│   └── completions.py # Completion endpoints
├── middleware/        # Auth and request processing
│   ├── auth.py        # CustomAuthenticationMiddleware
│   └── guards.py      # Scope guards
├── utilities/         # Shared utilities
│   └── errors.py      # Custom exceptions
└── tests/             # API tests

docs.title: Adding a New Endpoint
docs.text:
1. Define the route handler in routes/:
from litestar import get
from genjishimada_sdk.maps import MapResponse

@get("/maps/{map_id:int}")
async def get_map(map_id: int, conn: Connection) -> MapResponse:
    map_data = await maps_service.get_map(conn, map_id)
    return map_data
  1. Implement business logic in di/:
from asyncpg import Connection
from genjishimada_sdk.maps import MapResponse

async def get_map(conn: Connection, map_id: int) -> MapResponse:
    row = await conn.fetchrow(
        "SELECT * FROM maps.maps WHERE id = $1",
        map_id
    )
    if not row:
        raise CustomHTTPException(404, "Map not found")
    return MapResponse(**row)
  1. Add tests in tests/:
import pytest
from httpx import AsyncClient

@pytest.mark.asyncio
async def test_get_map(client: AsyncClient):
    response = await client.get("/api/v3/maps/1")
    assert response.status_code == 200
  1. Run tests:
just test-api

docs.title: Database Queries
docs.text:
Use AsyncPG with parameterized queries:

# Good - parameterized query
row = await conn.fetchrow(
    "SELECT * FROM maps.maps WHERE id = $1",
    map_id
)

# Bad - SQL injection risk
row = await conn.fetchrow(
    f"SELECT * FROM maps.maps WHERE id = {map_id}"
)

docs.title: Publishing Messages
docs.text:
Use BaseService.publish_message():

from di.base import BaseService
from genjishimada_sdk.completions import CompletionCreatedEvent

class CompletionsService(BaseService):
    async def create_completion(self, user_id: int, map_id: int) -> int:
        # Create in database
        completion_id = await insert_completion(...)

        # Publish event
        event = CompletionCreatedEvent(
            completion_id=completion_id,
        )
        await self.publish_message(
            queue_name="api.completion.submission",
            message=event,
            message_id=f"completion-{completion_id}",
        )

        return completion_id

docs.title: Project Structure
docs.text:
apps/bot/
├── core/
│   └── genji.py       # Main bot class
├── extensions/        # Feature modules (cogs)
│   ├── rabbit.py      # RabbitMQ service
│   ├── api_service.py # API client
│   └── completions.py # Completion handlers
└── configs/           # Configuration files
    ├── dev.toml
    └── prod.toml

docs.title: Adding a Queue Consumer
docs.text:
1. Define the consumer in an extension:
from extensions._queue_registry import queue_consumer
from genjishimada_sdk.completions import CompletionCreatedEvent

@queue_consumer(
    "api.completion.submission",
    struct_type=CompletionCreatedEvent,
    idempotent=True
)
async def handle_completion(
    self,
    event: CompletionCreatedEvent,
    message: AbstractIncomingMessage,
) -> None:
    # Send Discord notification
    channel = self.bot.get_channel(COMPLETION_CHANNEL_ID)
    await channel.send(f"New completion: {event.completion_id}")
  1. Test manually:

Trigger the event from the API and verify the bot processes it.

docs.title: Calling the API
docs.text:
Use the shared APIService attached to the bot:

async def get_user(user_id: int):
    return await bot.api.get_user(user_id)

docs.title: Adding a New Model
docs.text:
1. Define the model in libs/sdk/src/genjishimada_sdk/:
import msgspec

class Achievement(msgspec.Struct):
    id: int
    name: str
    description: str
    icon_url: str | None
    xp_reward: int
  1. Export from __init__.py:
from .achievements import Achievement

__all__ = ["Achievement", ...]
  1. Use in API and bot:
from genjishimada_sdk import Achievement

achievement = Achievement(
    id=1,
    name="First Completion",
    description="Complete your first map",
    icon_url=None,
    xp_reward=100,
)
  1. Run linters:
just lint-sdk

docs.title: API Debugging
docs.text:
1. Add debug logging:
import logging

logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)
logger.debug(f"Processing completion: {completion_id}")
  1. Run with debug mode:
cd apps/api
uv run litestar run --debug
  1. Check logs:

Logs appear in the terminal.

docs.title: Bot Debugging
docs.text:
1. Add debug logging:
import logging

logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)
logger.debug(f"Received event: {event}")
  1. Run the bot:
just run-bot
  1. Check logs:

Logs appear in the terminal.

docs.title: Database Debugging
docs.text:
1. Connect to PostgreSQL:
docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml exec genjishimada-db-dev \
  psql -U genjishimada
  1. Run queries:
SELECT * FROM maps.maps LIMIT 10;

docs.title: Import Errors
docs.text:
If you see import errors, re-sync dependencies:

just sync

docs.title: Database Connection Failed
docs.text:
Ensure Docker services are running:

docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml ps

docs.title: Tests Failing
docs.text:
Run tests with verbose output:

uv run --project apps/api pytest -vv apps/api/tests/

docs.title: Type Errors
docs.text:
Run BasedPyright to see all type errors:

uv run basedpyright apps/api

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: This guide helps you run the project locally for development or testing.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before you begin, ensure you have the following installed:

  • Python 3.13+ - Download Python
  • uv - Fast Python package manager (Installation Guide)
  • Docker - Required for PostgreSQL and RabbitMQ (Get Docker)
  • just - Command runner (Installation Guide)
  • Git - Version control

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: Follow these steps to set up the project:

docs.title: 1. Clone the Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/bkan0n/genjishimada.git
cd genjishimada

docs.title: 2. Install Dependencies
docs.text:
Use just to install all dependencies across the monorepo:

just setup

This command runs uv sync --all-groups, which installs dependencies for all workspaces (API, bot, SDK, and docs).

docs.title: 3. Configure Environment Variables
docs.text:
Create a .env file in the repository root and set the required variables:

# Discord
DISCORD_TOKEN=your_discord_bot_token

# Database
POSTGRES_USER=genjishimada
POSTGRES_PASSWORD=your_password
POSTGRES_DB=genjishimada

# RabbitMQ
RABBITMQ_USER=admin
RABBITMQ_PASS=your_password
RABBITMQ_HOST=localhost

# API
API_KEY=your_api_key_for_bot
APP_ENVIRONMENT=development

# S3-compatible storage (Cloudflare R2)
AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=your_access_key
AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=your_secret_key
R2_ACCOUNT_ID=your_r2_account_id

# Email
RESEND_API_KEY=your_resend_key

# Monitoring
SENTRY_DSN=your_sentry_dsn

If you are running the API on the host, set PSQL_DSN to point at the local Postgres port:

PSQL_DSN=postgresql://genjishimada:your_password@localhost:65432/genjishimada

docs.title: 4. Start Infrastructure Services
docs.text:
Start the database and RabbitMQ only:

docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml up -d \
  genjishimada-db-dev \
  genjishimada-rabbitmq-dev

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
Now that you've installed the project, learn how to:

  • Run the API and Bot - Start the services locally
  • Understand the Architecture - Learn how the system works
  • Make Your First Changes - Contributing guide

docs.title: uv Not Found
docs.text: If uv is not installed, follow the official installation guide.

docs.title: Docker Issues
docs.text: Ensure Docker is running and you have sufficient resources allocated. On macOS, check Docker Desktop settings.

docs.title: Database Connection Errors
docs.text:
Verify that PostgreSQL is running:

docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml ps genjishimada-db-dev

Check logs if the container is not healthy:

docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml logs genjishimada-db-dev

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
Detailed installation instructions for Genji Shimada.

Note

If you haven't already, review the Getting Started Overview for prerequisites and initial setup steps.

docs.title: Minimum Requirements
docs.text:
• CPU: 2 cores
  • RAM: 4 GB
  • Disk: 5 GB free space
  • OS: Linux, macOS, or Windows with WSL2

docs.title: Recommended for Development
docs.text:
• CPU: 4+ cores
  • RAM: 8+ GB
  • Disk: 10+ GB free space (for Docker images and databases)

docs.title: 1. Install Python 3.13+
docs.text:
macOSLinux (Ubuntu/Debian)Windows

Using Homebrew: 

brew install python@3.13


sudo apt update
sudo apt install python3.13 python3.13-venv python3.13-dev

Download from python.org and run the installer.

Ensure "Add Python to PATH" is checked during installation.

Verify installation:

python3.13 --version

docs.title: 2. Install uv
docs.text:
The project uses uv for fast dependency management:

macOS/LinuxWindows 
curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh

powershell -c "irm https://astral.sh/uv/install.ps1 | iex"

Verify installation:

uv --version

docs.title: 3. Install just
docs.text:
just is used as a task runner for common development commands:

macOSLinuxWindows 
brew install just

cargo install just

Or download from GitHub releases.

cargo install just

Verify installation:

just --version

docs.title: 4. Install Docker
docs.text:
Docker is required for running PostgreSQL and RabbitMQ:

  • macOS: Docker Desktop for Mac
  • Linux: Docker Engine
  • Windows: Docker Desktop for Windows

Verify installation:

docker --version
docker compose version

docs.title: 5. Clone the Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/bkan0n/genjishimada.git
cd genjishimada

docs.title: 6. Install Project Dependencies
docs.text:
Run the setup command to install all dependencies:

just setup

This command: 1. Creates virtual environments for all workspaces 2. Installs Python dependencies 3. Sets up development tools (Ruff, BasedPyright, pytest)

docs.title: 7. Configure Environment
docs.text: Create a .env file in the repo root and set the required values. See Configuration Guide for details. If you plan to run the API on the host, set PSQL_DSN to point at localhost:65432.

docs.title: 8. Start Infrastructure
docs.text:
Start PostgreSQL and RabbitMQ using Docker Compose:

docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml up -d \
  genjishimada-db-dev \
  genjishimada-rabbitmq-dev

Check that services are healthy:

docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml ps

docs.title: Verification
docs.text:
Verify your installation by running the linters:

just lint-all

All checks should pass (or report only pre-existing issues).

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Quick Start Guide - Run the API and bot
  • Configuration - Detailed environment setup
  • Development Workflow - How to contribute

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
Get the API and bot running locally in minutes.

Prerequisites

This guide assumes you've completed the Installation steps and have Docker services running.

docs.title: Running the API
docs.text:
Start the Litestar API server:

just run-api

This command: - Changes to the apps/api directory - Runs litestar run with hot reload enabled - Serves on http://localhost:8000

If you are running the API on the host, set PSQL_DSN in .env so it points at localhost:65432.

docs.title: Verify API is Running
docs.text:
Open your browser to:

  • API Docs: http://localhost:8000/docs
  • Health Check: http://localhost:8000/healthcheck

You should see the interactive OpenAPI documentation.

docs.title: Running the Bot
docs.text:
The bot is configured to call the API at the Docker service name (genjishimada-api-dev in development). The simplest local setup is to run the bot in Docker:

docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml up -d genjishimada-bot-dev

If you run the bot on the host with just run-bot, ensure the API hostname resolves (for example by running the API container and joining the same Docker network).

docs.title: Verify Bot is Running
docs.text:
Check the terminal output for:

Logged in as YourBotName#1234
Bot is ready.

In your Discord server, the bot should appear online.

docs.title: Running Both Services in Docker (optional)
docs.text:
If you want Docker to run everything:

docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml up -d

This will start API, bot, database, and RabbitMQ in containers.

docs.title: 1. Trigger a Bot Command
docs.text:
In Discord, send a command to test the bot:

/map search parkour

docs.title: 2. Check API Logs
docs.text: In the API terminal, you should see incoming requests from the bot.

docs.title: 3. Check RabbitMQ
docs.text:
RabbitMQ is not exposed directly in this repo; it is typically proxied via Caddy in production. For local checks, use container logs:

docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml logs -f genjishimada-rabbitmq-dev

docs.title: Make Code Changes
docs.text: The API runs with --reload, so changes are automatically picked up. For the bot, you'll need to restart the process.

docs.title: Run Tests
docs.text:
Test the API:

just test-api

This runs pytest with 8 parallel workers.

docs.title: Lint Code
docs.text:
Before committing, run linters:

just lint-all

This formats code with Ruff and type-checks with BasedPyright.

docs.title: View Logs
docs.text:
API logs: Displayed in the terminal where just run-api is running

Bot logs: Displayed in the terminal where just run-bot is running

Database logs: 

docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml logs -f genjishimada-db-dev

RabbitMQ logs: 

docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml logs -f genjishimada-rabbitmq-dev

docs.title: Stop Services
docs.text:
Stop Docker services:

docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml down

Stop API/bot: Press Ctrl+C in their respective terminals.

docs.title: Re-sync Dependencies
docs.text:
After pulling changes or switching branches:

just sync

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Bot Architecture - Understand how the bot works
  • API Documentation - Learn about API endpoints
  • Contributing Guide - Make your first contribution

docs.title: Port Already in Use
docs.text:
If port 8000 is already in use, find and kill the process:

lsof -ti:8000 | xargs kill -9

docs.title: Bot Won't Connect
docs.text:
1. Verify DISCORD_TOKEN is set in .env
  2. Check that the bot has proper permissions in your Discord server
  3. Ensure intents are enabled in the Discord Developer Portal

docs.title: Database Connection Failed
docs.text:
1. Verify Docker services are running: 

    docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml ps

  2. Check PostgreSQL logs: 

    docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml logs genjishimada-db-dev

  3. Verify database credentials in .env match docker-compose.dev.yml

docs.title: Operations
docs.text: Guides for deploying, configuring, and maintaining Genji Shimada in production and development environments.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This section covers:

  • Infrastructure - PostgreSQL, RabbitMQ, and cloud services
  • Docker Compose - Local and production deployments
  • Configuration - Environment variables and config files
  • Reverse Proxy - Caddy routing, domains, and TLS
  • Identity & Auth - Keycloak and oauth2-proxy
  • Cloudflare - DNS and CDN configuration
  • Monitoring - Grafana Alloy stack and dashboards

docs.text:

    Docker Guide

docs.title: Environment Configuration
docs.text:
Create a .env file in the repo root with the variables required by your services. At minimum:

APP_ENVIRONMENT=development
DISCORD_TOKEN=your_bot_token
POSTGRES_USER=genjishimada
POSTGRES_PASSWORD=secure_password
POSTGRES_DB=genjishimada
RABBITMQ_USER=admin
RABBITMQ_PASS=secure_password
RABBITMQ_HOST=localhost
API_KEY=secure_api_key_for_bot

Add optional values for Sentry, R2, and Resend as needed.

If you run the API/bot in Docker, set RABBITMQ_HOST to the service name (genjishimada-rabbitmq-dev or genjishimada-rabbitmq).

docs.title: API Health Check
docs.text:
curl http://localhost:8000/healthcheck

If the API runs in Docker without a port mapping, access it through your reverse proxy instead.

docs.title: Database Health
docs.text: docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml exec genjishimada-db-dev pg_isready

docs.title: RabbitMQ Health
docs.text: RabbitMQ is not exposed directly in this repo; use container logs or your reverse proxy setup.

  • Docker Compose Guide - Deployment strategies
  • Bot Configuration - Bot-specific config

docs.title: Cloudflare (DNS + CDN)
docs.text: Genji Shimada uses Cloudflare for DNS, TLS, and CDN delivery. This page captures the relevant records and R2/CDN settings used by the stack.

docs.title: Zones
docs.text:
• bkan0n.com
  • genji.pk

Both zones are proxied through Cloudflare. The origin IP is intentionally omitted from docs; store it in your private ops notes.

docs.title: DNS Records (Relevant Only)
docs.text: Only records used by Genji Shimada and related infrastructure are listed below.

docs.title: bkan0n.com
docs.text:
• bkan0n.com (A, proxied) -> origin IP (private)
  • auth.bkan0n.com (CNAME, proxied) -> bkan0n.com
  • portal.bkan0n.com (CNAME, proxied) -> bkan0n.com
  • grafana.bkan0n.com (CNAME, proxied) -> bkan0n.com
  • prometheus.bkan0n.com (CNAME, proxied) -> bkan0n.com
  • loki.bkan0n.com (CNAME, proxied) -> bkan0n.com
  • alloy.bkan0n.com (CNAME, proxied) -> bkan0n.com
  • cadvisor.bkan0n.com (CNAME, proxied) -> bkan0n.com
  • status.bkan0n.com (CNAME, proxied) -> bkan0n.com
  • translate.bkan0n.com (CNAME, proxied) -> bkan0n.com
  • dockhand.bkan0n.com (CNAME, proxied) -> bkan0n.com
  • cdn.bkan0n.com (CNAME, proxied) -> public.r2.dev

docs.title: genji.pk
docs.text:
• genji.pk (A, proxied) -> origin IP (private)
  • api.genji.pk (CNAME, proxied) -> genji.pk
  • dev-api.genji.pk (CNAME, proxied) -> genji.pk
  • dev.genji.pk (CNAME, proxied) -> genji.pk
  • rabbitmq.genji.pk (CNAME, proxied) -> genji.pk
  • dev-rabbitmq.genji.pk (CNAME, proxied) -> genji.pk
  • db.genji.pk (CNAME, proxied) -> genji.pk
  • docs.genji.pk (CNAME, proxied) -> genjishimada.github.io
  • cdn.genji.pk (CNAME, proxied) -> public.r2.dev

docs.title: SSL/TLS
docs.text: • Mode: Full

docs.title: R2 Buckets and CDN
docs.text:
Public CDN domains:

  • cdn.bkan0n.com
  • cdn.genji.pk

Buckets in use:

  • genji-db-backups
  • genji-parkour-images

docs.title: R2 CORS Policy
docs.text:
Allowed origins:

  • http://genji.test
  • https://dev.genji.pk
  • https://genji.pk
  • http://localhost:3000

Allowed methods: GET, HEAD Allowed headers: *

docs.title: R2 Response Headers
docs.text:
For wildcard hostnames *.bkan0n.com and *.genji.pk:

  • Cross-Origin-Resource-Policy: cross-origin
  • Vary: Origin, Access-Control-Request-Method, Access-Control-Request-Headers

docs.title: Docker Compose
docs.text: Deploy Genji Shimada using Docker Compose for development and production environments.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The project provides two Docker Compose configurations:

  • docker-compose.dev.yml - Development stack (API, bot, Postgres, RabbitMQ)
  • docker-compose.prod.yml - Production stack (API, bot, Postgres, RabbitMQ)

Both files expect the external Docker network genji-network to exist.

docs.title: Services
docs.text:
The development compose file defines:

services:
  genjishimada-api-dev:      # Litestar API
  genjishimada-bot-dev:      # Discord bot
  genjishimada-db-dev:       # PostgreSQL 17
  genjishimada-rabbitmq-dev: # RabbitMQ

docs.title: Starting Development Services
docs.text:
docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml up -d

To run only infrastructure services:

docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml up -d \
  genjishimada-db-dev \
  genjishimada-rabbitmq-dev

docs.title: Ports
docs.text:
Service Port Description PostgreSQL 65432 Database (host: 127.0.0.1)

RabbitMQ management UI is not exposed directly in this repo.

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Required in .env:

# PostgreSQL
POSTGRES_USER=genjishimada
POSTGRES_PASSWORD=dev_password
POSTGRES_DB=genjishimada

# RabbitMQ
RABBITMQ_USER=admin
RABBITMQ_PASS=dev_password

# API/Bot
APP_ENVIRONMENT=development
API_KEY=your_api_key_for_bot
DISCORD_TOKEN=your_discord_bot_token

docs.title: Verifying Services
docs.text:
Check service health:

docker compose -f docker-compose.dev.yml ps

docs.title: Services
docs.text:
The production compose file runs:

services:
  genjishimada-api:      # Litestar API
  genjishimada-bot:      # Discord bot
  genjishimada-db:       # PostgreSQL 17
  genjishimada-rabbitmq: # RabbitMQ

docs.title: Starting Production Services
docs.text: docker compose -f docker-compose.prod.yml up -d

docs.title: Ports
docs.text:
Service Port Description PostgreSQL 55432 Database (host: 127.0.0.1)

The API and RabbitMQ are not exposed directly; access is handled via your reverse proxy (e.g., Caddy).

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Create .env in the repository root:

# Application
APP_ENVIRONMENT=production

# Discord
DISCORD_TOKEN=your_production_bot_token

# PostgreSQL
POSTGRES_USER=genjishimada
POSTGRES_PASSWORD=secure_production_password
POSTGRES_DB=genjishimada

# RabbitMQ
RABBITMQ_USER=admin
RABBITMQ_PASS=secure_production_password

# API Authentication
API_KEY=secure_api_key_for_bot

# S3 Storage
AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=your_key
AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=your_secret
R2_ACCOUNT_ID=your_account_id

# Email
RESEND_API_KEY=your_resend_key

# Monitoring
SENTRY_DSN=your_sentry_dsn

docs.title: Health Checks
docs.text:
The API health check is:

healthcheck:
  test: ["CMD", "curl", "-fsS", "http://localhost:8000/healthcheck"]

docs.title: Viewing Logs
docs.text:
All services: 

docker compose -f docker-compose.prod.yml logs -f

Specific service: 

docker compose -f docker-compose.prod.yml logs -f genjishimada-api

docs.title: Restarting Services
docs.text: docker compose -f docker-compose.prod.yml restart genjishimada-api

docs.title: Networking
docs.text:
Both compose files attach to genji-network:

networks:
  genji-network:
    external: true

Create it once if needed:

docker network create genji-network

docs.title: Volumes
docs.text: The database and RabbitMQ use named volumes for persistence.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Infrastructure Guide - Understand the services
  • Operations Overview - Monitoring and backups
  • Bot Configuration - Configure the bot

docs.title: Identity & Auth (Keycloak + OAuth2 Proxy)
docs.text:
Genji Shimada uses Keycloak for identity management and oauth2-proxy to protect internal services (Grafana, Prometheus, etc.) behind the reverse proxy. The Keycloak stack lives in bkan0n/genjishimada-oidc, and the reverse proxy routes Keycloak through portal.bkan0n.com and oauth2-proxy through auth.bkan0n.com.

This page documents the deployed configuration and how it is wired to the reverse proxy and monitoring stack.

docs.title: How It Fits Together
docs.text:
• Keycloak provides OIDC issuer at https://portal.bkan0n.com/realms/master.
  • oauth2-proxy uses Keycloak OIDC to gate monitoring endpoints.
  • Caddy routes portal.bkan0n.com -> keycloak:8080 and auth.bkan0n.com -> oauth2-proxy:4180.
  • Grafana is configured to use Keycloak (see monitoring docs).

docs.title: Deployment (from genjishimada-oidc)
docs.text:
Keycloak and oauth2-proxy run in Docker with the following key settings:

Keycloak

  • KC_HOSTNAME=portal.bkan0n.com
  • KC_PROXY_HEADERS=xforwarded
  • KC_HTTP_ENABLED=true

oauth2-proxy

  • --provider=keycloak-oidc
  • --client-id=oauth2-proxy
  • --oidc-issuer-url=https://portal.bkan0n.com/realms/master
  • --redirect-url=https://auth.bkan0n.com/oauth2/callback
  • --allowed-group=monitoring

Secrets are supplied via environment variables and should not be stored in docs:

  • OAUTH2_PROXY_CLIENT_SECRET
  • OAUTH2_PROXY_COOKIE_SECRET

docs.title: Admin Console Configuration Summary
docs.text:
The current Keycloak realm export (redacted) shows:

  • Realm: master
  • Registration: disabled
  • Email login: enabled
  • Required credentials: password
  • OTP: TOTP enabled with 30s period and 6 digits
  • Auth flows: browser, direct grant, and conditional OTP flows enabled

Clients in the realm include built-in admin/account clients and service clients used by Keycloak itself. The oauth2-proxy client is defined in Keycloak and relies on OIDC standard scopes.

docs.title: Roles and Groups
docs.text:
From the export (master realm):

  • Realm roles:
    • Built-ins: offline_access, uma_authorization, default-roles-master, admin, create-realm.
    • Grafana roles: grafana-admin, grafana-editor, grafana-viewer (used by Grafana role mapping).
    • RabbitMQ roles:
      • rabbitmq.tag:administrator, rabbitmq.tag:management
      • rabbitmq.configure:*/*/*, rabbitmq.write:*/*/*, rabbitmq.read:*/*/*
  • Client roles: standard roles for master-realm, account, and broker.
  • Groups:
    • monitoring (for Grafana/Prometheus/Loki/cAdvisor access)
    • RabbitMQ (grants RabbitMQ tag roles)

If you are using oauth2-proxy group gating (for example --allowed-group=monitoring), make sure a monitoring group exists in the realm and that users are assigned to it.

docs.title: Clients
docs.text:
The realm includes built-in Keycloak clients plus service clients for internal apps. The notable custom clients are below:

  • oauth2-proxy
    • Redirect: https://auth.bkan0n.com/oauth2/callback
    • Standard flow enabled, confidential client
    • Default scopes include groups so oauth2-proxy can enforce group gating
  • grafana-oauth
    • Root/Admin URL: https://grafana.bkan0n.com
    • Redirect: https://grafana.bkan0n.com/login/generic_oauth
    • Protocol mappers: realm roles + hardcoded aud=grafana-oauth
  • rabbitmq-prod
    • Root/Admin URL: https://rabbitmq.genji.pk
    • Redirect: https://rabbitmq.genji.pk/*
    • Protocol mapper: hardcoded aud=rabbitmq
  • rabbitmq-dev
    • Root/Admin URL: https://dev-rabbitmq.genji.pk
    • Redirect: https://dev-rabbitmq.genji.pk/*
    • Protocol mapper: hardcoded aud=rabbitmq

Built-in clients also exist: account, account-console, admin-cli, broker, master-realm, security-admin-console.

docs.title: Client Scopes and Mappers
docs.text:
• groups client scope adds a groups claim via oidc-group-membership-mapper (used by oauth2-proxy).
  • grafana-oauth uses realm-role mapping and a hardcoded audience claim.
  • rabbitmq clients include a hardcoded aud claim of rabbitmq.
